page.title: 06LAXTON OPEN FIELDS
page.content: Laxton plays a unique part in the local history of Nottinghamshire and Britain. The village of Laxton is mostly owned by the Crown Commissioners and the farmers are all tenants. This is in order to preserve the unique medieval strip-farming system by which there sre three fields which are divided into strips, each farmer being allocated a certain number of strips in each field. The 'Court Leet' is held once a year and the fields are inspected to make sure that each farmer is working his strip correctly, fines are levied if he should plough over his limits or commit other misdemeanours. There is also common land which is used for grazing. Part of the South Field comes into the area studied.
